text: Thanks <@U5STGTB3J>! I guess that's partly what I was arguing for without realizing it. I'm a big fan of their Metaphors We Live By

elements.text: ! I guess that's partly what I was arguing for without realizing it. I'm a big fan of their Metaphors We Live By

text: To be clear <@UJK8MKYAZ>, I'm not saying that our maps don't model reality well. To the contrary, I think e=mc2 and Newton's map before it were great maps. But neither existed independently and we're discovered. The fact that Lebniz and Newton invented them at the same time can be explained by the fact that there were likely similar ideas in the air that set the stage for that invention. Just because all our experience takes place in the brain doesn't mean we cant have meaningful experiences. The brain is a wonderfully powerful virtual reality machine, combing all sorts of senses of the world into a cohesive experience that's pretty accurate for most things that are about our size, speed, and mass

text: Back from Xiamen, I'll exercise some restraint only to suggest humility (and fun speculation) is the bast way to approach metaphysics these days.  By way of analogy, consider how Aristotle's elements (earth, air, fire, water) of combinations of qualities experiential qualities (hot, cold, wet, dry) eventually gave way to a regular periodic table and subatomic particles.  Likewise, I feel that Cartesian meditation gives us some insight into the quality of being a thinking thing, but not so much what underlies it.

text:
<@U5STGTB3J> about graphs.  Yes, you're right about Graphs being trivially converted into free categories.  For non-free categories, you add in path equations "going this way is the same as going that way."

Graphs don't work so well for "dense" categories.  For instance, take rational numbers under â‰¤.  It's not free on a graph since any arrow is the composition of... well... many non-trivial ones.  BUT dense categories don't exactly come up a lot.

Also the Graphical Linear Algebra String Diagrams are related to but distinct from the objects as nodes and arrows as edges graphs.  Um, uh, here's a picture <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_diagram> that shows something... complicated is going on.

attachments.title: String diagram
attachments.text: In category theory, string diagrams are a way of representing morphisms in monoidal categories, or more generally 2-cells in 2-categories.

text: <@UJNJQD2AC> Yes, inspecting relationships!  Milewski says, "Category theory is extreme in the sense that it actively discourages us from looking inside the objects."  The intimating bit is that the some of the most interesting stuff happens in the relationships (adjoints) between relationships (natural transformations) between relationships (functors) between relationships (arrows).  I'll take a look at Eric's talks.

elements.text: Yes, inspecting relationships!  Milewski says, "Category theory is extreme in the sense that it actively discourages us from looking inside the objects."  The intimating bit is that the some of the most interesting stuff happens in the relationships (adjoints) between relationships (natural transformations) between relationships (functors) between relationships (arrows).  I'll take a look at Eric's talks.

text: <@U5STGTB3J> about objects being anything, the best part is that it from a categorical perspective, the specific definition doesn't matter, so you really get at the essence of how a thing works pretty much divorced from implementation details.  Opens you up to powerful analogies: here's a new data-structure, in what ways does it rhyme with others.
